replies.context: The Green Corn Moon is one of several names Native Americans gave to the full moon that lights up the night sky during the month of August. And it’s not because the moon itself appears green in color. Instead, this month’s moon was given the name Green Corn Moon because August is the month when the Native Americans’ corn was fully grown, but not yet ready to harvest.

context: Fake pictures. It wasn’t as big as it appears. It’s your eyes playing tricks on you. All about point of reference.

replies.context: Weeellll ... which point of reference gives a better idea of the moon's size -- when it's on the horizon, where you have something to compare it to, or when it's overhead, where you have nothing to compare it to?
The moon is closer to the Earth at some points in its orbit.  It really does seem bigger when it's closer.

"When the moon is near the horizon, the ground and horizon make the moon appear relatively close. Because the moon is changing its apparent position in depth while the light stimulus remains constant, the brain's size-distance mechanism changes its perceived size and makes the moon appear very large.”

Because I’m too lazy to explain myself.
That's all true, but the moon's distance from Earth isn't always the same.
1.5 inches per year is hardly discernible.
The difference in the moon's apogee and perigee is 30,000 miles
It’s called a telephoto lens compression effect, doofus.

context: The moon, to the human eye, cannot be perceived any closer or further away than any other time of the year or astronomical calendar. The degree of closeness is minuscule. Hold your pinky out at arms length and the tip will always just cover the moon no matter how "close" or "big" you "think" it is... even when it rises on the horizon and seems gigantic, still the same size. The dome of the sky is so large that once the moon enters that field of view it appears smaller or further away. At the horizon or lower in the sky, there are other things, like trees and buildings, to give an indication of size to your perception, at least.
